Dialogue.Stage Direction: A large space liner makes the jump to warp.

Dialogue.Line: We seem to be ahead of schedule, Secker.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Secker has a silly grin on his face.

Dialogue.Line: Great.
What?
The sooner the better.
Oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He makes a broadcast.

Dialogue.Line: Captain here. We're coming out of warp in thirty seconds.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the passenger deck, everyone is dressed in sunglasses, hooded silver jumpsuits and seated in rows of three seats, airplane style. A pleasant female voice makes an announcement.

Dialogue.Line: This is your flight computer speaking. We are about to go into orbit around the planet Azure. Passengers may leave their seats when the blue light comes on, but are requested not to remove their protective coveralls until instructed. Will passengers please remember that the Empress will be at seven tenths G, so please be careful when you first start to move around. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A red light suddenly lights up on the Captain's console.

Dialogue.Line: I've got a malfunction. Check it out, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Secker just sits grinning to himself.

Dialogue.Line: Secker, these coordinates are wrong. Did you set these?
What's a few degrees?
What's a few degrees? What's the matter with you, man? We're flying an interstellar cruise liner, not riding a bicycle!
So?
So we shall be going into the wrong orbit!
So?
Well, it could mean delays. It could. Oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rigg tries to correct it himself, then suddenly a small red spaceship appears right in front of them as they come out of warp.

Dialogue.Line: Oh no!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the Empress solidifies, the red ship is stuck into her forward section.

Dialogue.Line: Mayday, mayday, mayday. This is cruise liner Empress reporting collision. Space collision on approach to Azure.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two crewmen run to where the two ships have joined as alarm bells ring. The taller one uses a hand-held communicator.

Dialogue.Line: Damage control, report to the bridge.
The two ships are sticking straight through each other, sir.
Any blowouts? How's the pressure?
Everything's okay except we can't get through to some of the passenger sections. They're blocked off. The hull of the other ship, sir, is sticking right across the entrance to B deck.
A deck, report. A deck, are there any casualties?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Just static on the monitor.

Dialogue.Line: Have you got that damage report yet? Well?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rigg hauls the grinning, stoned Secker out of his chair and takes his place.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's all your fault, Secker. I'll carry the can. I'll lose my job but you, you'll never work in West Galaxy again. Go on, check the power, man. Come on, move yourself! This is an emergency!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Secker saunters over to a grid on the wall and presses a button.
The Tardis materialises close to a hatchway where the red ship is clearly visible. The Doctor and Romana come out.

Dialogue.Line: Hmm.
Fascinating.
Bit of a mish-mash.
Why wasn't there an explosion?
Well, one of the ships must have been in dematerialised form when it happened. Nasty. Could cause terrible problems. K9: Affirmative. The overlap areas are highly unstable, master.
Yes. Interfaces, I should say. K9: Affirmative.
I don't think we should interfere.
Interfere? Of course we should interfere. Always do what you're best at, that's what I say. Now, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On beige level,  blond man in a white pressure suit and carrying a helmet comes out of the airlock just before Romana and the Doctor walk round the corner.

Dialogue.Line: Who was that?
I don't know.
Shall we follow?
At our own pace.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man in the pressure suit is with the Captain.

Dialogue.Line: What are you going to do about the damage to my ship?
Mister Dymond, I am concerned with my ship, my crew, and nine hundred passengers. We're fully covered comprehensive on all third party damage, so don't worry.
I was involved in the most important job, and you just come crashing in on me, then you tell me not to worry? What am I going to do for a ship?
The Company will compensate you. Get in touch with your insurance people!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Romana enter unnoticed.

Dialogue.Line: Then I insist that you sign a document to the effect that this collision was entirely your fault!
I can't do that! What were you doing there, anyway? You were right in the middle of a launch and land window for commercial flights.
I was given complete clearance from Azure Control. You were off course!
Gentlemen, gentlemen, please. I'd say it was knock for knock, wouldn't you?
What? Are you a passenger?
No, no. We answered your mayday. I'm from Galactic Insurance and Salvage. Been having a look around. This is my assistant, Romana. I'm the Doctor. How do you do?
How'd you do. What's that?
Oh, K9? Well, a computer of sorts.
It looks more like a dog. Does he bark?
No. But he has been know to bite. Aren't we going to introduce ourselves?
Oh, yes. My name's Rigg, Captain Rigg.
We just met.
Yes. Er, this is Mister Dymond, the owner of the other vehicle involved in the, er, incident.
How do you do.
Salvage, you say?
Yes.
Yes, well, I can't discuss anything until I've spoken to the Company.
What about a better idea? Why don't we try to separate the ships?
Impossible.
I like doing the impossible.
If it's possible to get into the situation, theoretically it should be possible to get out of it.
Oh, you've spoilt it now.
But look, at the time of the collision this ship was partially dematerialised.
Therefore if we can recreate identical circumstances the ships could be separated.
It's just a question of exciting the molecules. Put your ship on full thrust.
Then full reverse.
Well, it's worked before, you know.
I preferred it when it seemed impossible.
Yes, well, it might work if I could get any power.
Are you pressing the right button?
Of course I am.
Can we switch on the wreck of the power unit?
Well, we could do, but it's dangerous.
Worth a try anything to get out of this mess.
It could damage your ship.
That's nice coming from someone who's just crashed into it. I'll risk it.
All right, all right. Where's the power unit?
Secker'll show you. Secker, take the Doctor to the power unit.
Good. No, Romana, you stay here. I might need you. I'll take K9. K9? K9? K9: Affirmative, master. Affirmative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Secker, the Doctor and K9 leave.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Romana, why don't you and Mister Dymond wait in the lounge?
Right.
Just down the corridor on the right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana and Dymond leave. Rigg goes to a monitor and calls up the details of Galactic Salvage and Insurance. Formed London Earth 2068. Liquidated 2096.
Secker stops grinning and leans against the wall.

Dialogue.Line: You go down here to section five, then left into the shuttlebay, and down to level B. You can't miss it.
Hold on, I thought the idea was you'd show me.
I've told you, haven't I? What's the difference? I'm busy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Secker walks off.

Dialogue.Line: How very odd. K9: Affirmative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They follow Secker as he staggers into a darkened area and watch as he uses a keycard to open a filing cabinet. He takes out a small container and leaves. The Doctor enters, uses his sonic screwdriver to open the cabinet and gets another container out. He opens it and offers some of the contents to K9 on his hand for analysis.

Dialogue.Line: Any idea what this is, K9? K9: A fungus. Source of the drug XYP.
Yes? K9: Dangerous, addictive. Known as Vraxoin.
Vraxoin? I've seen whole communities, whole planets destroyed by this. It induces a kind of warm complacency and a total apathy. Until it wears off, that is, and soon you're dead. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A bespectacled man with a vaguely teutonic cum slavic accent is holding forth to Romana. His female assistant stands nearby.

Dialogue.Line: It is my ambition to become the first zoologist to qualify and quantify every species in our galaxy. One more trip and I may achieve it.
Are you planning another?
Ah, well, the next is always on my mind, but is a question of finance. I was hoping to meet a sponsor on Azure, but this accident may have ruined my chances.
A sponsor?

Yes, well, the government used to fund me, but the galactic recession put a stop to that. Now all they do is to assign me special travel facilities on government subsidised spacelines, but first class.
What's that machine?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A free standing object about a metre tall with a diamond shaped box on the top.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, that is my CET machine. The Continuous Event Transmuter. It is an invention of mine. I will show you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He switches the machine on, and a whole wall sized screen set up a little way forward of the end of the lounge lights up. It shows a landscape with mountains in the distance, some trees and mist on the ground.

Dialogue.Line: It looks as if you've invented the cinematograph.
What you see may seem to be just a mere projection, but it is in fact a matter transmutation.
You see, when we've collected the specimens for study, they're converted into electromagnetic signals and stored on an event crystal in the machine.
And they go on living and evolving.
In the crystal.
This image projection allows us to see them whenever we wish. The flora and the fauna are actually in a crystal. I hope you can appreciate what a technical achievement that is.
A crude form of matter transfer by dimensional control.
Crude?
Well, prototype. And you could have problems with it.
Problems? But it works perfectly.
Nothing works perfectly.
Oh, yes, but
What about the materialisation collision? It's caused all sorts of unstable matter interface. They'll probably affect the dimensional matrix of your machine.
The what?
Have you thought of that?
Are you claiming superior knowledge?
Equal, perhaps.
I wish everyone would stop showing off and get something done about my ship.
We seem to have to have a slight problem, Azure. We're doing out best to sort it out and meanwhile we'll continue to orbit. Rigg out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor harrumphs.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Doctor. The man from Galactic.
Yes.
Back so soon?
Yes. I'll tell you something about your man Secker.
What about him?
He ran away.
Yes, well, he has been behaving rather strangely. Seems to be in a different world.
Yes. Perhaps he's unwell. Can I have a look at your log and check to see if he's been to any planet where he might have picked up Vraxoin?
Doctor, this is the milk run. Station nine to Azure, Azure to Station nine. A straight charter for the whole season.
What about one of the passengers? One of them could have been the carrier, so to speak.
No, Doctor. They've all had prevocation checks. The Azurian authorities insist on it.
Anyone else?
Tryst.
Tryst?
Yes. A zoologist. He arrived at Station nine after a long expedition with his equipment and he's looking for a holiday.
Where had he been?
Well, all over. Oh, but he's all right. We checked him over.
Yes, but I'd still like to know where he's been.
Yes, and I'd like to know just who you are.
Me?
Yes.
Well, I told you. I'm from Galactic.
Galactic went out of business twenty years ago.
I wondered why I hadn't been paid.
Now that's not good enough.
That's what I thought. Where can I find Tryst?
Well, he's in the first class lounge.
Good, good. Look, you try and find Secker and meet me in the first class lounge and
Yes, and
No, no. Do you want this ship repaired or not?
Well, yes, of course I do.
Well then, just find Secker and meet me in the lounge in five minutes.
But I
Bye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Secker is blissed out again, and walking towards the intersection of the two ships.

Dialogue.Line: Secker, report to the bridge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He disappears into the void.

Dialogue.Line: Really? Then where did you go?
We went through the Cygnus gap.
What?
And then we did a slingshot over to a small system, just three planets, M37. You know?
I do.
The second planet supports life in a very early stage of evolution. The molluscs, the algae, the primitive insects. I can show you.
No, no, no, that's perfectly all right. I'm just interested in the voyage. It's fascinating.
Here you are, a copy of my log. I published it to go with my lectures.
The Volante.
Yes, the name of my ship.
And you invented this marvellous machine to collect your specimens? You know, I knew a man once who toyed with an idea like this. What was his name? Professor Stein?
Professor Stein?
Yes.
Oh, a dear friend. He was my mentor. We worked on this idea together before he died, of course. Then we stopped. You knew him?
Yes, well, by reputation. He once gave a seminar on the
Doctor, Doctor, Doctor. All very well reminiscing but don't we have an urgent problem to deal with? I'm anxious to be on my way.
Of course. You're extremely anxious to be on your way.
Yes. You see, I didn't actually expect a spaceliner to materialise halfway through my ship today.
No.
Doctor, we can't locate Secker. My men are still looking.
Could you take me to the power unit yourself?
Well, yes, all right.
Good, good. Tryst, thank you very much for your story. Very interesting. We must have a chat about this machine of yours sometime.
Yes.
And about the notion of your capturing alien species for your own private zoo.
Zoo?
Yes.
No, Doctor, this is important scientific research. I am helping to conserve endangered species.
By putting them in this machine?
Oh, yes.
Ah, yes, of course. Just in the same way a jam maker conserves raspberries.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Rigg leave.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, don't mind him. He just likes to irritate people.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana picks up the copy of Tryst's log.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, well, he has a right to criticise. I suppose. Still, I'm very pleased to have someone of intellect to speak with again, after such a long voyage cooped up with all the same peoples.
How many were on your ship?
Ah, well, to begin with there was ten, but we lost one.
How?
He died.
How did he die?
He died.
Did you find out anything from Tryst?
No. K9 checked all the planets he'd been to. K9: Affirmative.
None of them could explain Secker's condition.
Are you certain?
Absolutely sure.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They round a corner to see the interface of the two ships.

Dialogue.Line: Oh dear. K9: Caution. Area of overlap is highly dangerous. Molecular structure of the two ships is incompatible, causing matter interface.
What?
Fascinating. The two ships are rejecting each other. Molecularly speaking, that is.
Like a tissue transplant, you mean.
Exactly. Exactly. Is there another way to the power unit?
Well, we can try from below the shuttlebay. We'll have to cut our way through. I could put in a request for lasers, have them sent up from Azure.
That won't be necessary. I've got my own equipment.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana goes to the CET machine and turns the dial on the top from Bros to Ranx. Other choices available are Gidi, Eden, Zil, Vij, Darp and Lvan. Another landscape appears, this time a plain whose trees have round balls on the top. Gidi has a duststorm blowing. Eden is a dark, dense, lush tropical forest with birdsong. Romana walks forward. There is a human male partially concealed in the foliage. He moves out of sight. Della enters the lounge.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
Oh, I was just having a look. I hope you don't mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Della switches the machine off.

Dialogue.Line: I don't, no.
Then why have you switched it off?
I don't mind. Tryst does. This machine's his baby. Nobody touches it except for him.
Has it ever gone wrong?
No. Why should it?
Pff. Lots of reasons. Do you think I could just have a look at that last one? Eden, I think it's called.
No, not that one.
What's the matter?
It's just that Eden brings back such unpleasant memories for me. That was where we lost the other crewmember.
Oh, I see. He was a friend of yours.
More than that, but it doesn't matter now. Excuse me.
We won't be able to make it, Doctor. The place to cut through is beyond that overlap.
Where's the power unit?
Up there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man's scream comes from inside the interface. Rigg and the Doctor run in.

Dialogue.Line: Caution, master. You're entering a matter interface.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They drag Secker out. He has three large scratch marks down the side of his face.

Dialogue.Line: What the devil did that?
I don't know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rigg uses his communicator.

Dialogue.Line: Medics level four. Meet you at the elevator. Move!
K9, see if you can find anything in there. K9: The mist is a matter interface and therefore dangerous, master.
Just go near the edge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They drag Secker away.

Dialogue.Line: Affirmative, master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 trundles in then backs straight out again.

Dialogue.Line: Sensors will not function in the environment, master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor accompanies Rigg on the elevator to level 4 where the Captain puts Secker onto a gurney brought by two medics.

Dialogue.Line: Let's get him to the sickbay, quick!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor returns to where the drugs were stashed. Someone wearing a very large ring on their left little finger has got the cabinet open. The Doctor looks around then notices a gun pointed at him.

Dialogue.Line: Hello. No wait, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gets shot. The mystery figure takes the Vraxoin sample from his coat pocket and leaves.
Medics work on Secker's injuries in an isolation booth. Rigg and Della watch through an observation window.

Dialogue.Line: It was an attack by somebody, or something.
Horrible. But why?
I don't know. Have you ever seen anything like that before?
No. No, I haven't.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tryst enters.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Captain, I get your message. What is the problem?
Look at this.
Where did this happen?
Down under the shuttlebay. Secker was in one of the matter interfaces.
Yes, that could be the answer. Who knows what forces exist in an unstable zone such as that?
You didn't hear the scream. Tryst.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They move away from Della.

Dialogue.Line: You didn't bring any live specimens on board my ship, did you?
Oh, no, Captain. I assure you. No, all my specimens are laser crystal recordings.
Good, good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He returns to the observation window. The chief medic shakes his head.
K9 leads the way down a dim corridor.

Dialogue.Line: This way, mistress.
How far? K9: Approximately seven metres and closing.
Doctor! What happened?
I. Bushwhacked!
What? K9: Please clarify. Statement does not compute.
Bushwhacked! K9: Oh. Bushwhacked. Cowardly attack by a person or persons unknown.
Gone.
Has something been stolen?
Yes. Someone aboard this ship is smuggling drugs. Vraxoin.
Vraxoin!
Yes.
I thought that was stamped out long ago.
Yes.
The only known source was destroyed, wasn't it?
That's right. They incinerated an entire planet. Someone's found another source.
What is the man doing? He comes up with a marvellous idea then he fiddles about.
I've got my own problems, Dymond, including a dead navigator. And now the Doctor says he's going to blast his way into the shuttlebay. How do I explain a great gaping hole in the side of the ship?
I just wish he'd get on with it. I've got a schedule to keep.
So have I.
Doctor, this machine.
What, the lift?
No, not the lift, the CET machine.
What about it?
It doesn't just take recordings.
Oh no, the animals themselves are converted into magnetic signals, and their habitats.
So he's left bald patches on the planets he's visited?
Yes. The CET machine's just an electric zoo. For cages, read laser crystals. Either way, the animals are trapped inside.
I hope so.
What do you mean?
Well, you saw how primitive the device was. It's terribly unstable. This ship is full of unstable matter zones. It gives me the creeps. It wasn't just a mirage that attacked Secker.
Killed him.
What?
Secker's dead. They couldn't save him.
That's a pity. He might have been able to say what attacked him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The lift finally arrives.

Dialogue.Line: I asked Tryst, but he couldn't help either.
Right, first things first. Romana, you take care of the CET machine.

Dialogue.Character: (The Doctor puts Romana into the lift. ROMANA
Dialogue.Line: What are you going to do? DOCTOR: Separate the ships. Come on, Rigg.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana runs into the empty lounge and switches on the CET machine. She sets the dial to Eden and walks towards the projection.
K9 fires at the alien creature and it retreats.

Dialogue.Line: What the devil was that?
I don't know.
And what in the name of the suns is it doing on board the ship? First a collision, then a dead navigator, and now a monster roaming about my ship! It's totally inexplicable.
Nothing's inexplicable.
Then explain it!
It's inexplicable. We'd better put it back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He puts the cut section of bulkhead back into its hole and K9 welds it in place.

Dialogue.Line: It must have been that that got Secker.
Maybe, but Secker was a dead man already.
What do you mean?
He was taking Vraxoin.
Oh, no.
None of my passengers could have brought it on board the ship.
Dymond's ship?
No, I've scanned it. Still, I'll scan the Empress again.
Yes, the Vraxoin must be found.
Yes, it's bad stuff.
Bad stuff? It's the worst. I've seen whole planets ravaged by it while the merchants made fortunes.
Your people knew it would be on board, did they?
What, my people?
Well, you're an agent, aren't you?
No! I'm the Doctor. I keep telling you that.
Yes, but who do you work for?
Work for? I don't work for anybody. I'm just having fun.
Everybody works for somebody.
If there's any Vraxoin on board, it'll show up on the scan.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rigg presses buttons, and a schematic of the Empress comes up on the monitor. The scan is a pair of vertical lines slowly moving from bow to stern.

Dialogue.Line: Can you check the whole ship with this?
Every nook and cranny. Nothing in the forward section.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scan lines vanish briefly then restart.

Dialogue.Line: Secker kept his in the luggage area. I took what was left then someone took it from me. After stunning me, that is.
Who?
Yes, who indeed.
Nothing.
Is there any possible shield against that scan?
No, no, no.
Really?
Well, any shield would be too small to hide any useful quantity of the stuff.
Yes, a small thick tube. Very mysterious.
But this drug is hardly our most pressing problem.
Yes, I know, I know. We've got to get the ships separated.
Yes, but how to get through to the power unit?
Yes. You know, there might be a way we can do it using my ship.
Your ship?
Yes.
Yes, where is your ship, by the way?
Oh, around.
Well there you go again. How do I know I can trust you?
Yes. Or I you, Captain.
Oh, that's hardly the point.
Yes, but who's helping whom?
All right, what do you want me to do?
Right, when I give the word, I want Dymond to put his ship on full power. Trust me, Captain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Someone in heavy boots leaves Romana lying on the floor just before Della comes in.

Dialogue.Line: Romana! Are you all right?
I don't know. I think so.
What happened?
Oh. I must have fainted.
Was it anything to do with the machine?
Yes. I was watching the projection, and then I. Oh. It isn't on anymore. I just felt hot. I must have fainted.
I asked you not to put that particular image on.
Yes, I know, but as I was on my own I thought I'd just have another look. Besides, you assured me that it was perfectly safe, didn't you.
Of course. I'll tell you what. I'll get you something to drink. You look quite pale.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Della goes through to the vending area just off the main lounge, opposite the projection, and punches buttons on the dispenser.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Della.
Oh, hello, Captain.
That's just what I was after.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A mystery hand pours the contents of a small bottle into the dispensed drink.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's for Romana. She's fainted. I'll get one for you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She takes out the glass and puts it on a table.

Dialogue.Line: Fainted, you say? It wasn't something she saw, was it?
No, I think she just felt hot.
Oh, why don't I just take this one.
Help yourself.
Thanks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rigg leaves with the dosed glass, and Della takes the fresh one back to the lounge proper.
The Doctor brings a piece of equipment out of the Tardis, with the power cord trailing inside.

Dialogue.Line: I want to get as close as possible. K9: Predict only sixty percent chance of success, master.
Tell me, K9, how is it that, how is it you always look on the black side of things?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor expands the equipment into a purple laser on an adjustable stand.

Dialogue.Line: Here am I, trying a little lateral thinking, and what do you do? You trample all over it with logic. K9: It is a question of the localised power available, master. I predict
Sixty percent. I heard you, I heard you. But it's worth a try. Now, come on. Let's go and find your mistress. Come on. Come on.
I've got to be away soon or I'll lose my contract. A year's work for nothing. Do you realise that? It's all your fault, Captain. You were off course.
And you shouldn't have been in that sector.
Gentlemen, please. Blaming each other won't help anything. The only person who seems to be able to do anything constructive is the Doctor, and we must support him.
Yes, yes. I just wish we knew more about him. You know he's got some bee in his bonnet about drug smuggling on the ship.
Drug smuggling?
Yes. There isn't any evidence to back up his suspicions. There isn't a trace of any drug anywhere on the ship at all. Still, I think that's the least of our worries.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And finished his dosed drink.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure about that? That creature came through the picture?
Yes.
You were right about this machine. It is unstable, and that creature's escaped from its electric zoo. I wonder where it came from?
A planet called Eden.
Eden?
Do you know it?
Well, it rings a bell.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tryst enters.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Doctor. I have a message for you. Oh, I'm so delighted that you are taking an interest in my CET machine.
I'm absolutely amazed.
Yes. Well, it is rather impressive, isn't it.
No, I mean I'm amazed at you, Tryst, using a machine like this when it's still so primitive. The whole thing's utterly unstable.
Well, I value your opinion, Doctor.
Good, good. I value my life and this machine makes me fear for it.
It does?
Yes.
Well, what do you think is so wrong?
Well, at a rough guess I'd say the spatial integrator, transmutation oscillator, hologistic retention circuit. Shall I go on?
Yes.
Dimensional osmosis damper?
Er, the what?
You mean you haven't even got a dimensional osmosis damper? Professor, you don't realise how unstable this machine is.
Yes, yes, all right, Doctor. In spite of your interest, I have decided to shut it off until I've had a chance to make some adjustments.
Well, I'm delighted to hear it.
Yes, no, no, and it doesn't matter what you are saying, I'm going to switch it off.
Good!
Yes. Oh, I nearly forgot.
What?
The message. The separation of the ships. Dymond is waiting for you.
I'm on my way. Romana, off to the Tardis. I'll give you details later. Tryst! Don't you forget to switch that off.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rigg is rather too happy with life.

Dialogue.Line: You know what, Dymond? The Empress has eaten your ship. Ha ha! Eaten it. DYMOND [on monitor]: I don't see why you find it so funny. After all, you stand to lose your Captaincy over this.
Yeah, I know, I know, I know. I mean, that's funny in itself, isn't it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: Stay there, K9. Stay there. Right then, Dymond. Ready for another try? I want you to put your ship on full power. Not now. When I tell you. DYMOND [on monitor]: Right, Doctor.
Where are you going to be, Doctor?
Here, if it's all right with you. Romana's in my ship. I can keep an eye on things from here.
Oh, be my guest.
Thank you. Romana? ROMANA [on monitor]: All ready, Doctor.
Good, good. We're just waiting on Dymond. K9? K9: Yes, master?
Just in case your prediction is correct, go along to one of the blurred areas and take a reading for me. K9: Affirmative.
Good dog. K9: Success only sixty percent owing to factors of localised energy. DYMOND [on monitor]: Ready when you are, Doctor.
Good. Start building up power.
Well, I'll leave you to it, Doctor. I'm thirsty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rigg leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Romana, get ready. What did you say? Romana, get ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 arrives at an interface point, which clears. He trundles forward towards a door labelled power unit, then it goes blurred again. He vanishes.

Dialogue.Line: I'll have to switch off, Doctor. My ship's breaking up.
No, no. Come on, Dymond, now. Don't lose your nerve. We're almost there. Just a bit longer. DYMOND [on monitor]: No, she won't take it!
Romana, switch off. Something's wrong. I'll go and find K9. He's taking a reading for me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 is at the power unit door when the Doctor arrives at the blurred area.

Dialogue.Line: K9? K9, where are you? K9? He must have slipped through. Good boy, K9! A figure in passenger coveralls and dark glasses comes out of a door behind the Doctor. He turns.)
Ah, could I have a word with you, please?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The figure runs away. The Doctor follows. The figure runs into the lift, so the Doctor takes the stairs down. The figure gets out at a lower floor just before the Doctor gets there. The chase continues into the passenger area.
The Doctor bursts into Passenger Pallets 67-90, to discover that the coveralls and glasses are what all the passengers are wearing.

Dialogue.Line: What's going on?
I'm looking for a man dressed just like you.
When are we going to land? We've been stuck for ages. How much longer?
Which way did he go? This way? MAN 2: Maybe that's the entertainment?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor's quarry goes out through the rear door. The Doctor follows him through another compartment.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And another.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And another.

Dialogue.Line: What's the meaning of this? Why aren't we going down to Azure?
I promise you, everything possible is being done. WOMAN 2: But what are they doing about it?
Here, have a jelly baby and don't forget to brush your teeth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The running man gets back to the lift and heads back up. The Doctor does not run up the stairs.
The man is waiting at the top of the stairs when the Doctor arrives in the lift. He produces a gun then runs round the corner to an interface area.

Dialogue.Line: I only wanted a word with you, whoever you are. You took something from me, old chap. I'd rather like to have it back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man runs into the mist, and the Doctor follows.
The drugged Captain Rigg is finding life highly amusing at present.

Dialogue.Line: Little ships in big ships. Ships in bottles. Russian dolls, that's what it's like. You remember those?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tryst shakes his head.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I do. I wonder if the people who made them realised they were making a model of the universe?
A what? Eh?
As a primitive concept, you know.

I don't think the Captain is in a mood to discuss philosophy. Can I get you anything, Rigg? A caffetine capsule, perhaps? RIGG: No, let's talk about life while I await my dismissal and eventual execution for dereliction of duty and I really couldn't care less.
Oh, come on, Captain. The Doctor may still come up with something.
The Doctor. The enigmatic, almighty Mister Fix-it. He's failed again and I don't care about that either.
Not yet. I'd better go and see what he's doing.
Oh, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Hey. Hey, it's them. They're the ones who are doing the drug smuggling, you know? So the Doctor isn't going to do anything at all, right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They seem to be running forever.

Dialogue.Line: I just want to talk to you. I promise you, you'll enjoy it. Stop!
Okay, so the Doctor's an agent. Yes, that's it. He's a narcotics agent.
And we must give him all the help that we can. Here, drink this. It'll make you feel better. There. And Romana, is she an agent too?
What if she is? I mean, I don't care. What does it matter? I mean, nothing matters at all.
Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mystery man jumps the Doctor from behind.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He wrestles the Doctor to the ground, then the creature from the wall arrives.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Where are you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The growling can be heard, then the creature walks out of the mist. Someone shoots it several times before it backs away, then the Doctor crawls out.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor! Are you all right? There's a creature in there. It's horrible. We've got to get away. What were you doing in there? Come on!
Romana, stop. Do you know I've just come through an interface? That's no mean feat. I'm not even sure I'm all here.
You mean you've been right through to the other side?
Yes, I have, I have. Did you see anyone while I was in there? Coveralls, dark glasses.
Well, someone shot at that creature and drove it off.

It must have been the chap I was chasing. The fellow who jumped me in the luggage section. Still, I know something about him now. He dropped his radiation band in the struggle just now. Look. Volante.
Tryst's ship?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tryst switches on the CET machine. It is set to Eden. Della enters.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter with Captain Rigg?
Oh, I think he found the whole thing a little too much, but he'll be all right.
Good. I thought you told the Doctor you wouldn't use the CET again?
Ah, yes, but I'm using for his benefit, Della.
Oh?
Yes. The Doctor is looking for someone on this ship who is carrying Vraxoin.
Vrax?
Yes, Vrax. The Doctor is probably a narcotics agent, so we are all under suspicion. So I thought perhaps that we might put our own house in order, as it were.
How do you mean?

Well, Della, I've been thinking about Stott, our sadly lamented crewman and your close friend, and his strange behaviour on Eden. Might it be him who discovered a new source of Vrax? But he died, of course, didn't he.
What are you suggesting?

No, Della, I'm sorry to do this, but I must be certain about a few things, not the least to eliminate the possibility that the Volante and my expedition was used to transport this detestable substance. Now let us assume, for a moment, that it was Stott. He must have had an accomplice. Someone who would take over from him when he died.
Are you accusing me?
No, no, no, I'm not accusing you, Della. I'm just asking you. Was it Stott?
Of course not. I knew him. He wouldn't do anything like that.
Then why did he disappear for two hours on Eden, the day before he was killed?
I don't know. I don't know anything about that.
Of course.
Rigg said Tryst and Della were the only ones from the expedition to come aboard.
A stowaway?
Well, we have to ask Rigg.
He's hit the bottle.
What?
He doesn't care about anything anymore. He just laughs and giggles the whole time, sick grin on his face.
Well, that doesn't sound like drunkenness to me.
Vraxoin? Where from?
Well, inside the projection set. It's the only place. Romana, we've got no choice.
What do you want to do?
What we have to do. We've got to get inside that machine. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tryst comes round the corner behind them.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Doctor. Doctor, Rigg has told me about the drugs.
Oh, really.
Yes. Doctor, I believe I can help you over this problem.
You can?
Yes. Er.
Romana, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, I'm very sad to say that I think the drugs were smuggled on board my ship, and I'm pretty certain I know who it was.
You are?
Yes. One of my crew. But he was killed. But I think he passed the drugs on before he died.
Yes.
Yes. To Della.
What!
I question her, of course, but she wouldn't admit it.
Well, maybe it's because she's innocent. How'd you know she did it?
Doctor

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An alarm sounds.

Dialogue.Line: Calling the Doctor. Would the Doctor please report to the bridge immediately.
Thank you, Tryst.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tryst leaves the way he came. The Doctor walks round the corner to Romana.

Dialogue.Line: Did you hear that?
Della, indeed.
Have located power unit. Awaiting instructions, master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 sticks his laser out at the creatures surrounding him.
The Doctor and Romana enter to find Dymond with two black-leather clad men. The little peaked caps mark them out as officious jobsworths even before they open their mouths.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Doctor. This is Waterguard Fisk and Landing Officer Costa of the Azurian Excise. I've been telling them
Good, good. Now listen.
Can I see your ident plaque?
Can I just tell you something, please?
Let me see it. Now.
On this ship
The plaque, please, sir.
(to Romana) And yours, please.
I haven't got one.
Neither have I.
That's extremely serious.
Drugs. Vraxoin.
Names and dates of birth. Come on, come on.
Romana.
Romana who?
Will you please listen? Someone aboard this ship is smuggling drugs.
Name and date of birth.
Well how would I know? I don't even know who he is yet.
Your name and date of birth.
Oh, well, I'm called the Doctor. Date of birth difficult to remember. Sometime quite soon, I think.
I would advise you not to play the fool with us.
We wouldn't want to.
Would you please listen? Vraxoin is the biggest killer drug in existence and it's on this ship!
All in good time.
There's no good time. The criminals must be caught.
Costa.
Right. I'll start with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Costa runs an electronic sniffer wand over Romana.

Dialogue.Line: She's clean.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It's the Doctor's turn.

Dialogue.Line: You're wasting your time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Beep beep

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
Vraxoin. Traces of it in his pocket.
So, the criminals must be caught, eh, Doctor?
Oh, for heaven's sake, Fisk
You're under arrest.
All right. Can I just say one thing at this moment?
Well?
It's simply that. Look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor points to the monitor. Fisk and Costa turn, and the Doctor and Romana run out.

Dialogue.Line: We've only got a few seconds.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hits the door close button, trapping Fisk, Costa and Dymond inside briefly.

Dialogue.Line: Well, how do you like Eden?
I don't.
Might give us a few answer, though.
Which way?
Let's go east.
How do you know which way is east?
Well, I don't. We'll go that way and we'll call it east.
Why not call it north?
All right, we'll call it north.
North-east?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something large roars nearby.

Dialogue.Line: (sotto) Can we go, please?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They tiptoe off into the dark jungle, followed by one of those creatures.
Fisk, Costa and Dymond get the doors open.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They stare briefly at the projection of Eden.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, you may as well give yourself up.
There must be another way out of here.
I don't know.
There's got to be. What's that?
It's a door.
It's locked. Get Tryst.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dymond leaves.

Dialogue.Line: How did you know we could get into the projection?
The same way I knew we could get into the Tardis. Tryst doesn't realise what he's stumbled on. At least, I don't think he has.
A relative dimensional field?
Yes. All this is recorded on laser crystal. When it's played back
It's restructured on an intradimensional matrix.
Yes, well, roughly speaking.
So without the dimensional osmosis damper, everything gets mixed up together and we can just walk straight into the projection.
Yes.
And anything else can just walk straight out.
Yes.
I've never met such idiots as those customs men.
Idiots? They're worse than idiots, they're bureaucrats. They just exist to tangle people up, wrap them round and round in red tape until they can't move. Romana?
Yes?
I can't move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Roots are wrapping themselves around their legs. The Doctor has one round his throat. A giant Venus flytrap opens its mouth and starts to reel him in.

Dialogue.Line: Don't wriggle, don't wriggle. It'll realise it's got dinner.
Dinner?
Yes. It eats people.
Doctor!
Quick, over there. The root.
Root?
Root, root!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana pulls a very big root over to the Doctor, who bites it. Green yuk spurts out and the plant relaxes its grip on them, then collapses.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right?
Yes.
Let's get out of here.
You know, that didn't taste at all bad.
I can't turn it off. The selector's gone. It's difficult to believe the Doctor would do this. Why?
The man is a criminal, that's why.
I don't see the logical connection.
Well, criminals are like that.
Oh.
Now, this other exit, can you open it?
It leads to the first class bathroom. The Doctor couldn't open it, it opens by personal key.
It's the only way he can

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tryst opens the door. Fisk and Costa go in to search for the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: I think the Doctor is in serious trouble, Dymond. It's a pity. Such a brilliant mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: More nearby growls. The Doctor and Romana duck down by a large rock.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Shush. It's waiting for us to make any kind of sound.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The creature lumbers slowly past.

Dialogue.Line: (sotto) It's gone. Now take care.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They take a few steps forward. The Doctor smiles then the creature leaps up in front of them. Romana squeals and they jump back. A man comes out from behind a plant and shoots at the creature.

Dialogue.Line: What was that?
I don't know. Hello there, thank you very much. We're terribly grateful to you for saving our lives.
Who are you?
The name's Stott.
Stott! Stott of the Tryst expedition?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hands over the radiation band.

Dialogue.Line: Yours, I believe. I'm the Doctor, this is Romana. We're travellers and

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Growls

Dialogue.Line: Come on, this way.
I know a safe place. Follow me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stott brings them into a prefabricated building with diamond windows, shelves, table and chairs, bunk, and various bits of equipment.

Dialogue.Line: Not bad, not bad at all. How long have you been here?
A hundred and eighty three days. They left me for dead on Eden. I tried to get back here to call the ship, and I got caught up in the event transmuter.
How did you get those marks?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Three scars on his face, like Secker had.

Dialogue.Line: A mandrel. The thing I saved you from.
Mandrel. Doctor, they're called mandrels.
Well, Stott, you've got some explaining to do. A hundred and eighty three days here?
Yes. I thought I was going to be stuck here for the rest of my life. There were a few times when I felt like blowing my brains out. The hardest thing was being able to look out and see Della.
Yes, yes, quite. Tell me, when did you first discover you could get out of the projection?
After the accident. Something must have gone wrong with the CET machine. The edge of the projection was shimmering.
Really?
I decided I had nothing to lose, so I walked straight through it and found myself on the Empress. Then I took one of the passenger coveralls so I could walk about unnoticed.
Why didn't you tell Tryst and Della you'd got out?
Because of what I am and what I'm doing.
Really?
I'm a Major in the Intelligence section of Space Corps, on a special assignment to find out who's drug running.
Ah ha. You thought it was me, didn't you.
For a while. Then I overheard you and Romana talking in the lounge.
Tryst thought it was you, and now he thinks it's Della.
Tryst's a fool. He knows nothing. He didn't even realise his expedition was being used to transport a new sort of Vrax that someone had found.
Yes, if you store in on crystal in the CET machine, it can't possibly show up on a molecular scan.
He must have arranged somewhere along the line for a pick-up. They'd have to get the stuff out of the projection and pass it on.
Yeah. You've got the stuff I had?
Just a tiny sample. Secker must have found it. He may even have been involved himself.
Yes, but more important is where the main supply is hidden and where it comes from.
All I know is that it's in Eden somewhere. I've been searching all this time. No result.
Then we've got to get the dimension projection sealed off again, which means doing what we first came to do.
And what's that?
Separate the ships. Tell me, if we go out of the projection in that direction, do we come to the power unit?
Yes, you can get out of the projection any way you want.
Good, good. Then that's what we'll do. Come on. Well, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stott turns the lights out and shuts the door after himself.
K9 is there when Stott walks through the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Identify.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Romana come out.

Dialogue.Line: Look out, Doctor.
It's all right, he's mine.
What is it?
It's just a perfectly ordinary electric dog. K9: Master, I have located the power unit.
Good, good. Now listen, K9. This is Stott. He's a friend. All right? K9: Affirmative.
Good. Let's get to work. (Stott and K9 stand guard.)
Liquid hydrogen, turbopump exhaust, reactor core, pressure shell. Right.
Doctor, do you really know how to get this thing going?
Of course I do. I can start anything from a steam engine to a Tardis. Have you got a match?
What for?
I want to jam this switch down.
Would a toothpick do?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The one in the Doctor's mouth.

Dialogue.Line: Perfect. K9: Master, during your absence I encountered alien creatures in this area.
Mandrels, K9. K9: Name noted, mistress.
You'd better guard the door, K9. How many were there? K9: Five units, master.
Five! I'd better get a move on or they'll be all over the ship.
Hadn't we better deal with them first?
No, no, no. Until the ships are separated and the projection is stabilised, it'd be like trying to bail out a small boat with a
Sieve?
Yes.
We're doing everything we can. The skipper's got WOMAN 2: We should have been on Azure hours ago. My passengers asked me to represent them, to take our complaint to the Captain.
You must understand, he's very busy in the emergency. He's doing everything possible to get you to Azure.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The flight attendant presses the lift button. The doors open and a mandrel pounces on the woman. A second one gets him as he sounds the alarm.
Rigg laughs at the scenes of carnage on the monitor, as mandrels attack the helpless passengers.

Dialogue.Line: What's going on, Captain?
Nothing much, nothing much.
What's happening? What are those things?
They're a sort of judgment on us all.
What? I'll have you shot for this, Captain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He uses the intercom.

Dialogue.Line: Bridge here. Emergency. The passengers on pallet sixty seven are under attack. All armed crewmembers proceed to pallet sixty seven immediately! (to Rigg) I shall be charging you with gross neglect of duty. The passengers should be your first concern, yet I find you drunkenly looking on as they are attacked and killed! Well?
They're only economy class. What's all the fuss about?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is working inside a control unit.

Dialogue.Line: Is that the one, Romana? Romana, was that
Mandrel!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mandrel grabs the Doctor in a bear hug.

Dialogue.Line: K9, quickly!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 shoots the mandrel and it falls.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, they're coming from both ways.
I've got to get this finished. Romana, did you check the cable to the reactor?
Yes, I'm pretty sure it was that one.
Well, check it. I need to be absolutely sure.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She hesitates at the mandrel. The Doctor kicks it.

Dialogue.Line: It's perfectly all right. It's quite dead.
If you say so.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She jumps over the body.

Dialogue.Line: Was it the one?
No, sorry. It's the one below.
It's a good thing you checked. I could have caused a spectacular explosion.
All ready to go now?

Nearly. Two things. One, I need to know whether the power on the bridge is on maximum. Two, the demat has to be switched on from the Tardis at exactly the same time I switch on this old gas oven. All right?
All right.
Good.
Captain, this ship is a disaster area. I'm placing you under arrest for gross neglect of duty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Costa twists Rigg's arm behind his back.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, it's really nice being arrested.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Costa takes Rigg out.

Dialogue.Line: Now, about the, er, mandrels?
Yes.
Mandrels. We need to seal them off and then destroy them. I'll send for heavy weapons.
I'd rather if they're not killed, if that's possible.
The things are killing our people, man. What do you suggest?
Some sort of tranquillising drug?
We haven't got time for pussyfooting around! I can't think why you care so much about such ugly, disgusting things.
It's all a matter of conservation. If they are killed, the whole species will have gone.
Look, I'm in charge here. I'll do what I think is best. CREWMAN [on monitor]: Level B. Two mandrels have got into the fuel section.
Then kill them. CREWMAN [on monitor]: Well, we're worried about hitting the fuel tanks if we fire.
You see what I mean, Tryst? Keep them under surveillance, and if they move out of there, destroy them. CREWMAN [on monitor]: Aye, aye, sir.
Has the Doctor been seen in that sector? CREWMAN [on monitor]: No, sir.
Yes, well, pass the word around that if he offers the slightest resistance to arrest, shoot him. CREWMAN [on monitor]: Shoot him, sir?
He's a criminal, isn't he? What else do you do with criminals? CREWMAN [on monitor]: Sir.
Stott, I want you and Romana to go back through the jungle. K9, I want you to go back the way you came. K9: Negative, master. Blurred zone still operative. These zones are matter interfaces.
Will you listen to me, please? Stott and I came through one. It's perfectly all right if it's on the edge of a hull. All you need is a little determination. K9: Affirmative. Determination, master.
Good. Now, when you get through, I want you to go back to the demat machine set up near the Tardis, and when I whistle, you switch it on. Right? K9: Affirmative.
Good.
What about you? You're not going to be here when the power unit comes on, are you?
No, no. I'm going to rig myself a little time device. Could I borrow your watch, please?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes the timepiece from Stott's wrist.

Dialogue.Line: Certainly.
Good. Is that on ship's time? Right. Now, I'll give you till 20:25 to reach the bridge and put the power on. I'll set my device so I can escape in good time.
What about the mandrels? You won't have K9 or a gun.
I'll have to use my wits. Off you go. Take care. Look out for excisemen. I don't think they like us very much. Off you go then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stott, Romana and K9 leave.

Dialogue.Line: Twenty oh one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fisk has assembled all four of the ship's crew to give them his orders.

Dialogue.Line: I want this ship searched from top to bottom. If you see the Doctor or his lady companion, arrest them. If they resist, kill them. Right, get on with it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fisk gets into the lift.

Dialogue.Line: Shall I put it on destruct?
I think not. We'll see how things develop. We'll keep in touch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Roar!

Dialogue.Line: Look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stott shoots at the mandrel, making it stagger just enough for them to run past and away. Then it collapses.
The Doctor has taken Stott's watch apart and is putting pieces into the control unit. Behind him, the 'dead' mandrel stirs. The time is 20:16.

Dialogue.Line: Plenty of time. (The Doctor bends down for a piece of equipment just as the mandrel takes a swipe at him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 enters the interface.

Dialogue.Line: You go back and guide the Doctor through.
What about the excisemen?
I'll manage.
Right. (Stott turns back. Romana runs out of the projection and through the lounge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor slips through a gap between two control units which is too small for the mandrel to follow. He goes back behind the units to where he was working, gives it a final blast of sonic screwdriver then switches on the countdown. The ticking attracts the mandrel.

Dialogue.Line: No! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mandrel smashes the annoying timer. The flash and bang finally kills it. The Doctor stares as the creature crumbles into a heap of steaming powder.

Dialogue.Line: Vraxoin. Of course! So that's it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana ducks out of sight into a cloakroom when she hears voices approaching.

Dialogue.Line: How much longer do we have to stay up here?
Until the job's finished. How many casualties so far?
Here's the list. Twelve dead, twenty nine injured. Enough for a small war.
You know what this means?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Costa uses a drinks dispenser in the wall opposite the cloakroom.

Dialogue.Line: What?
Almost certain promotion.
Promotion?
It's bound to be, a situation as big as this. It'll sort itself out and in the end we'll have two tailor-made suspects, the Doctor and the girl. We'll be the golden boys of the day.
We don't actually know anything about those two.
You found the traces of Vrax in the Doctor's pocket. What more do you want?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fisk and Costa move off towards the lounge. Romana comes out of hiding and heads carefully for the bridge.
Everything is as the Doctor left it, with the Tardis door wide open.

Dialogue.Line: In position. Waiting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is trying to repair the damage to the controls that the mandrel caused.

Dialogue.Line: Twenty twenty-one? I'll never do it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two ships are separated. Romana picks herself up from the floor. Fisk is still down, so she kicks his gun out of his hand and runs out. Fisk is about to follow when -

Dialogue.Line: He's done it! Empress, this is Hecate. Full separation has been achieved. No damage to report. Empress, this is Hecate. Respond please.
I read you, Dymond. What are you doing on your ship? DYMOND [on monitor]: I came aboard to get a couple of GP guns to help against the mandrels. The ships separated whilst I was here.
Yeah, right. I'll check the Empress for damage.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He punches a row of buttons.

Dialogue.Line: Good as new. DYMOND [on monitor]: Waterguard Fisk, sir. I request your permission to continue my journey. I will not be pressing any claim on the Empress.
No, no, no, no. I might need you as a witness. There's bound to be an enquiry. DYMOND [on monitor]: But if I delay my departure for even an hour I'll lose my contract!

Look, Dymond, I haven't raised this with you before, but now I'm telling you officially. When this accident occurred, you, as Rigg rightly pointed out, was in a prohibited area. Now that makes you liable to at least a considerable fine. Now, if you try to get away, I'll nail a writ to your bulkhead! Do you understand, Dymond? DYMOND [on monitor]: Yes.
Right. Come back aboard as quick as you can. DYMOND [on monitor]: Yes, right away.
Operation one hundred percent successful, mistress.
Yes, I know, but I can't find the Doctor. Can you locate him, K9? K9: Affirmative. Sensors indicate that the master is not aboard the ship, mistress.
What!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is lying unconscious in a dark room.
An injured passenger is wheeled into the room opposite the Tardis. Romana enters.

Dialogue.Line: Della, have you seen the Doctor?
No, I've been too busy with the casualties. The Excisemen want him shot on sight, and you.
Yes, I know. I wonder, could you bare to talk about Stott?
Why?
Well, Tryst told us that you and he might be implicated in the drug smuggling. Now, we know it's not you and Stott, but it would help if you could tell me what happened.

All right. Stott and I were together. He was acting very strangely. He kept telling me to go back to the shuttle. I could see he was worried. There were mandrels prowling about, but I know it wasn't that. He was looking for someone.
For whom? Did he say?
No. Then it happened. A shot came from the forest. He was only stunned, but a mandrel came out from behind. I ran. I ran. I couldn't help myself, I just ran. I was so afraid.
It's all right, Della. Anyone would have done the same.
The mandrel killed him.
How do you know?
Tryst told me. He showed me a visprint. It was horrible.
Stott didn't die. He's here on this ship.
What? He can't
He is.
But where? I must see him.
Not yet. Now, we must find out who is smuggling the Vraxoin. We know it's something to do with the Eden projection. Stott may be able to help us.
I knew it was him looking at me. In the Eden picture, someone staring out, only I couldn't believe it. I thought I was seeing a ghost. Romana, what can I do to help?
First of all, we'd better find the Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor wakes up. The first thing he inspects is a wicked looking free standing laser-like device.

Dialogue.Line: How very odd. How very strange.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He looks out of the porthole to see the Empress a short distance away.

Dialogue.Line: How very clever.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He hides as Dymond enters. Dymond uses a small keyboard, smiles at the results on the screen, and leaves again. The Doctor crawls over and calls up the results again. Eden Project: projected turnover Gal Credits: z13,000,000. Overheads z3,900,000. Profit margin: 9,100,000.

Dialogue.Line: The profits on human suffering.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves that room, and ducks behind a bank of equipment as Dymond goes past. He tiptoes through the airlock where Dymond is suiting up again, and gets into the back of the shuttle. Dymond gets in and plugs his helmet into the shuttle air supply. The Doctor puts himself into suspended animation. The shuttlebay doors open and Dymond flies back to the Empress, as promised to Fisk.

Dialogue.Line: Right. Dymond's on his way. Now, any sign of the Doctor?
No. They're searching A deck at the moment.
I think I know where the Doctor went.
Where? Why didn't you say so before?
You may find it hard to believe.
Make me believe, professor.
I think he went into the projection.
What projection?
The CET machine. The image has become an unstable dimensional field.
Oh. If he went into it, he's got to come out the same way. Costa, check the guard on the lounge.
Right.
I'll join you later.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Costa leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Tryst, what would the Doctor want inside the projection?
I can only imagine that one of the crew of my expedition found a new source of this er, what is this thing called?
Vrax.

Ja, Vrax. Yes, Vrax, and placed it in the transmute location. Yes, then he informed the Doctor. So the Doctor comes on board and makes the pick-up, which fits in with your own wonderful theory, does it not?
Yes, yes. Only, why did he bother to separate the ships?
Perhaps it's because, as you say, he is a criminal.
That would be it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Della comes running up.

Dialogue.Line: Did you find anything?
Only a mandrel.
Oh, he must be somewhere. K9: Negative, mistress. I have scanned the ship and I detect no

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9's 'ears' whirr.

Dialogue.Line: What is it, K9? K9: This way. The Doctor has just come aboard.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dymond's shuttle has docked, and Dymond heads for the lift. Romana, K9 and Della hide round the corner.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, K9.
Hello, Doctor.
Hello, Romana. Everything all right?
What happened to you?
I got caught in the interface when the two ships separated. Hello, Della.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The lift arrives.

Dialogue.Line: Look out! Quick!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two armed crewmen are there. One catches Della but the other is stunned by K9 as the Doctor and Romana duck into the stairwell. K9 leaves. The crewman checks on his fallen colleague then returns to Della.

Dialogue.Line: What were you doing with them?
Finding out a few things.
Well, you'd better tell Fisk about it. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Romana return.

Dialogue.Line: Bit uncivil of them, pointing their guns at us like that.
They've had orders to shoot.
Yes. Tell me, what would you use an inchuka laser for?
An inchuka laser can be used to carry thousands of telecom messages
Shush. Could it carry a CET projection crystal?
From what I've seen of Tryst's set up, I should think so. Why?
Because Dymond's got a CET projection machine aboard the Hecate with an inchuka laser attached.
Then Tryst and Dymond are the smugglers?
It looks like it. The only way of convincing Fisk is to catch them in the act of transferring the Vraxoin. K9: Master, detect units approaching.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It is Stott, backing away as he fires at a mandrel.

Dialogue.Line: Stott, leave it to K9!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 zaps the creature to the floor.

Dialogue.Line: What happened to you, Doctor?
Never mind about us. We know who the smugglers are.
Who?
Dymond's the pick-up man, and the smuggler's Tryst himself.
Tryst?
Yes. The Vraxoin's kept on the Eden crystal. They're about to transfer that crystal to the Hecate.
Do you know what the source is?
Yes. Those things.
The mandrels?
Yes. One of them attacked me in the Power unit. Poor thing was electrocuted, burnt to a powder.
A powder? You mean?
Vraxoin.
No wonder I couldn't find it.
Yes. They can make the transference across space by means of the inchuka laser.
Can you prove it?
Yes.
How?
I let them do it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Della's crewman escort is grabbed by a mandrel out in the corridor. She screams and runs into the bridge where Tryst is putting on a spacesuit like Dymond's.

Dialogue.Line: Tryst, there's a mandrel out there!
It's all right, Della. Dymond has a gun.

What are you doing, Tryst? You weren't thinking of leaving the ship, were you? You've got to help the Doctor. You knew the CET was unstable so it's all your fault. You must help them get the mandrels back into the projection.
Is that what he's doing?
Yes!
Good. In that case, I'm right behind him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is examining the CET machine when Costa and two crewmen burst through the main door, and Fisk in from the washroom with anther two. The Eden projection is running.

Dialogue.Line: Put your hands up, Doctor!
You're arresting the wrong man, you know, Fisk.
That's enough, Doctor.
Stop!

Dialogue.Character: (Stott runs out of the projection. FISK
Dialogue.Line: Who are you? Keep your hands up!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fisk takes Stott's proffered ID.

Dialogue.Line: It's Tryst and Dymond you want.
Tryst, did you know Stott was alive?
Alive? He can't be!
You fired that shot, didn't you, that last day on Eden.
I didn't want to, Della. He forced the situation on himself.
You! You're smuggling the Vrax.
Della, I, er
Yes is the word you're looking for.
No, it started just as a little thing, just to help me over a slight financial difficulty. The cost of the expedition, that was bankrupting me!
But Vrax is destroying people by the millions!
I had to continue my research! Without me, many of those creatures would have become extinct!
I think a few million people becoming extinct is rather more serious.
Ah, but they had a choice. It was their own fault that they became addicted.
Huh! Like Rigg, I suppose. Did he have a choice or was he tricked?
That was unfortunate.
But necessary.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A mandrel enters. Della escapes.

Dialogue.Line: No, don't kill him! He's valuable!
Tryst, I can't even stop it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Finally the mandrel collapses.

Dialogue.Line: Della! Get after her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dymond runs out. Tryst shoots the main ship's control console and follows.
Della arrives at the body of the crewman. The mandrel is still there in a doorway. Dymond comes up from behind and shoots Della, then K9 and Romana come round the corner.

Dialogue.Line: Stop him, K9, quickly!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana goes to help Della and K9 goes round the next corner.

Dialogue.Line: Mission aborted, mistress.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mandrel comes out of the doorway and threatens Romana. K9 shoots it.

Dialogue.Line: More important to protect you as programmed, mistress.
Thank you, K9. That was close. K9: Two metres, to be precise, mistress.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor comes running up.

Dialogue.Line: Romana, what happened?
Dymond shot Della. She's wounded, but she'll be all right.
The callous wretches. They'll be making the transfer to the Hecate by now.
All personnel locate and apprehend passenger Tryst and pilot Dymond. They may try to leave the ship. And with reference to the previous order regarding the Doctor, cancel it.
Is sooner than I thought.
Better move. They'll have an interceptor after us.
I think not. I smashed the communications system. They're cut off from Azure.
If we don't get them on the ship, we've lost them.
The Empress is faster, isn't she?
There's no pilot, no navigating officer. Could you fly her?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stott shakes his head. The Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: Gentlemen, once more into the

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Then he sees the destroyed communication unit.

Dialogue.Line: What happened?
Tryst and Dymond have got away.
They won't go anywhere without the Eden crystal. That gives us a little time.
To do what?
Well, now that the ships are separated, we can at last stabilise the CET properly.
Good. Isn't it?
Yes.
Yes, but what does it mean?
It means, Fisk, that we can finally clear this marauding menagerie back into the projection, which is exactly where Dymond will want it.
Yes. But what are we going to do?
Give him what he wants. We have to bait the hook properly, don't we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stott and a crewman use their weapons to herd a pair of mandrels along.

Dialogue.Line: Keep them moving. We should meet up with Fisk soon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fisk, Costa and a crewman have got three more, but the crewman gets knocked out before they can get them moving again. Meanwhile, Dymond's shuttle arrives back on the Hecate.
The two groups have met up and are nearly at the lounge.

Dialogue.Line: The guns are fading!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mandrels turn and start to drive the men back. The Doctor appears and whistles to get the mandrel's attention. Then he uses the dog whistle to calm them and lure them into the lounge. Very Pied Piper of him.
He gets them to the edge of the Eden projection.

Dialogue.Line: I'm going inside now and I may be rather a long time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blowing the whistle, he leads the mandrels back into Eden.
The Doctor tries to circle round and get out again, but trips on a vine.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. Oh gosh, oh lord, oh Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He leads them out of camera shot.

Dialogue.Line: Steady, steady. This way. Not that way! This. Oh! Oh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bits of foliage come flying into shot.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, my fingers, my arms, my legs! Ah! My everything! Argh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fisk and Costa put away their guns.

Dialogue.Line: It's all over, then. Switch off the machine.
No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor appears from the. His coat has been ripped to shreds with just the lining left and the arms hanging off his wrists. A mandrel appears behind him and he runs out.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, switch it off!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana switches off the CET machine.

Dialogue.Line: Phew. Well done, Romana.
Well, Doctor?
What now?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes his own pulse.

Dialogue.Line: Romana, you've got two minutes fifty eight seconds to rebuild this machine.
What, this?
Yes.
CET?
Yes!
Are you joking?
Do I look as if I'm joking? Well?
Well, I'll need a screwdriver.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tryst is lining up the laser when Dymond enters.

Dialogue.Line: How's the attitude setting?
It couldn't be better. Are you ready to get us out of here as soon as I've made the transfer?
I can fire the engine from here.
Good. I'm ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tryst switches on the laser.

Dialogue.Line: Increase the gain on the matrix modulator. Well?
Up five points.
Five points. That's not enough. We're going to need some more power from somewhere.
We could put the jump leads on K9.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He just happens to have them around his neck. Romana clips them onto K9's 'ears'.

Dialogue.Line: Good dog, K9. Come on, put your leads on. Put your leads on. There.
Are you connected, K9? K9: Affirmative, mistress.
What are you hoping to achieve?
I want to increase the range and power of this machine. How many points now, Romana?
Ten and building.
Ten and building. That's much better. We're going to be all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Then the laser beam hits the top of the machine where the Doctor is resting his hands. He jumps.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right?
Yes, yes. It was just a little shock, that's all.
They're making the transfer.
That means they'll get away.
Shush! Quiet, quiet. Reverse the setting on the transmutation reflex. It's all right, it's all right, it's quite safe.
They've made the transfer.
So?
They'll get away!
Will you please reverse the setting on the transmutation reflex!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana sticks the sonic screwdriver inside the CET.

Dialogue.Line: K9? K9: Yes, master?
I want you to find the Hecate. Give me her position. K9: Affirmative.
Good dog.
Good. We've done it. Let's get out of here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dymond fires up the Hecate's engines and she starts moving away.

Dialogue.Line: Forty seven point three, vector seven niner niner in seven seconds.
Forty seven point three vector seven niner niner. I hope you're right, K9.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the Doctor operates the CET machine, everything shimmers briefly.

Dialogue.Line: Well, good.
What's happened?
Have you ever heard the expression, hoist by his own petard?
Yes, but you haven't done anything.
Good, well what

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Excisemen enter.

Dialogue.Line: So, Doctor, your plan has failed miserably. There's no way we can catch them now.
On the contrary, Fisk. I've already caught them. There they are, all yours.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the projection screen, Tryst and Dymond stare at them in horror.

Dialogue.Line: But I, I
All I did was increase the range of this machine and brought them back. Matter transmutation, you see. And because the projection's still unstable, all you have to do is pluck them out.
You heard him. Pluck them out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two crewmen fetch Tryst and Dymond out of the projection.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor! Doctor, I didn't want to be involved in all this. Tell them. Tell them that I only did it for the sake of funding my research. You understand all this. You're a scientist.
Go away.
What?
Go away.
Oh!
Well, how are you now, Della? Good? Good?
I'm fine now, thank you, Doctor. I'm relieved the nightmare's over.
The nightmare's here, on the Eden crystal.
And here's the rest of Tryst's electric zoo.
It never was meant to be a zoo. It really was a conservation exercise for most of us.
I think the best way of conserving the poor creatures trapped in these crystals is to project them back to their own planets, don't you?
But you've dismantled the CET.
Oh, we've got far more sophisticated stuff in the Tardis. Do it in no time.
What about the mandrels and the Vraxoin?
The mandrels have a perfect right to exist. In one way Tryst was right. Humans do have some kind of choice. Let's just hope that no one else discovers the secret.
I can only think of one animal who'd be comfortably at home in an electric zoo.
Really? What's that?
I don't think we want to tell them, do we, K9? K9: Negative, mistress.
